description: Two or more teams competing for the same limited resources such as engineers, budget, infrastructure, or time. Requires negotiation and data-driven decision making to find fair resolution.
example_situation: Product and Infrastructure teams both needed the same 3 senior engineers for Q1 priorities. Product wanted a new feature, Infrastructure needed critical security updates.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to resolve a conflict over resources.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Reels and News Feed teams both needed the same 3 ML infrastructure engineers for Q1. Reels was launching creator monetization with a Super Bowl campaign deadline - $10M in ad commitments. News Feed needed ranking model improvements to address a 3% engagement decline affecting ad revenue.

Task: As the eng manager over ML infrastructure, I needed to find a resolution that protected both business priorities without escalating to VP level.

Action: I met with both tech leads to understand true constraints. Reels' hard deadline was Feb 1 for Super Bowl; News Feed's engagement fix had no external deadline but was impacting Q1 revenue projections. I analyzed the work and found Reels needed 2 engineers for 4 weeks on model serving, while News Feed needed the third engineer for ranking experiments. I proposed: 2 engineers to Reels through Feb 1, third engineer starts News Feed immediately. I also identified that one Reels task could be parallelized with existing News Feed infrastructure work - saving 2 weeks total. I committed to daily standups to catch blockers early.

Result: Reels creator monetization launched Jan 30, drove 23% increase in creator content during Super Bowl week. News Feed ranking improvements shipped Feb 15, recovering 2.1% of the engagement decline. Both leads presented jointly at quarterly review as a collaboration win. This became our template for cross-team resource allocation.

description: Engineers or tech leads disagree on architecture, design patterns, technology choices, or implementation approach. Often involves trade-offs between different valid solutions.
example_situation: Senior engineer wanted to keep the monolith for simplicity, I advocated for microservices for the new payment system citing scalability needs. We had heated debates in design reviews.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you disagreed with a technical decision.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our principal engineer wanted to build Instagram Stories' new interactive stickers as part of the existing Stories monolith, citing team familiarity. I believed we needed a separate service because interactive stickers required real-time state sync across millions of concurrent viewers - the monolith couldn't handle that load pattern.

Task: I needed to convince him with data without damaging our relationship, since we'd be working together for years on Stories infrastructure.

Action: Instead of arguing in design reviews, I spent a weekend building a load simulation. I modeled the Super Bowl scenario: 100M concurrent viewers, each sticker interaction needing sub-100ms sync. The monolith's request pattern showed 40% of requests would timeout. I also created a migration plan using the strangler pattern - we could extract incrementally, not big-bang. I presented to him 1:1 first, acknowledging his valid concerns about operational complexity. I proposed we'd share on-call initially to address his maintenance concerns.

Result: The data convinced him - he hadn't modeled the concurrent viewer scenario. We extracted the service in 6 weeks. During the actual Super Bowl, we handled 112M concurrent viewers with p99 latency of 67ms. He later cited this in a tech talk as an example of data-driven technical decision making. We've collaborated smoothly on 3 more projects since.

description: Different stakeholders (PM, engineering, leadership) have conflicting views on what should be built first. Involves balancing business needs, technical debt, and team capacity.
example_situation: PM wanted to ship 3 new features for a sales demo, engineering team wanted to address mounting tech debt that was slowing development by 40%.
typical_question: Tell me about a time stakeholders disagreed on priorities.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our PM wanted to ship 3 new Marketplace features for a holiday shopping push - seller analytics, price comparison, and shipping estimates. My team had been tracking mounting tech debt in the product catalog service - our test suite took 3 hours and deployments had dropped to twice weekly because engineers feared breaking things.

Task: I needed to find a path that addressed the real business need (holiday revenue) while not letting tech debt cripple us further.

Action: I analyzed what the holiday push actually required. Talked to the Marketplace growth lead and learned only shipping estimates was a must-have; the other two were 'nice to have' based on seller feedback. I proposed a deal: deliver shipping estimates in 3 weeks, then spend 2 weeks on test infrastructure before other features. I showed data projecting that without fixes, we'd slow to weekly deploys within a month - right during holiday peak. I offered to personally present the tradeoff to the Marketplace director, taking the heat off the PM.

Result: Shipped shipping estimates in 2.5 weeks - it drove 8% conversion lift for holiday. Used remaining time to parallelize tests, cutting runtime from 3 hours to 25 minutes. Deployment frequency returned to daily. The other two features shipped in January without the holiday pressure. PM later said she'd been skeptical but now always validates 'must-haves' with data before committing.

description: Your team is blocked by or blocking another team. May involve blame, finger-pointing, or unclear ownership. Requires diplomacy and focus on shared goals.
example_situation: Mobile team blamed backend team for launch delays, backend said mobile kept changing API requirements. Both teams were frustrated and trust was breaking down.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you dealt with conflict between teams.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: WhatsApp iOS and Android teams were blaming the backend team for delays in launching encrypted group calls. iOS said backend kept changing API contracts. Backend said mobile teams kept requesting changes after specs were finalized. Trust had broken down - engineers were refusing to join cross-team meetings.

Task: As the tech lead with relationships on both mobile teams from a previous project, I volunteered to mediate and find a path forward.

Action: I ran separate retros with each team - not to assign blame but to document specific pain points with examples. Found the root cause: no API contract process. Backend would write APIs, mobile would implement, find issues in integration testing, request changes via Slack. I proposed a contract-first approach: Protocol Buffer specs reviewed by all three teams before any implementation. For the immediate crisis, I facilitated a 4-hour working session with all teams mapping remaining work on a shared board. I physically stayed in the room to redirect any blame to 'what do we need to ship.'

Result: Launched encrypted group calls 2 weeks later. Implemented the contract-first process which reduced API-related back-and-forth by 75% over the next quarter. The three tech leads now do weekly syncs. The process was adopted by 4 other cross-platform features at WhatsApp. I was asked to document it as the standard for WhatsApp cross-team API development.

description: Interpersonal friction with a colleague due to different communication styles, work habits, or personalities. Not about the work itself but about how people interact.
example_situation: A colleague was consistently dismissive and condescending in code reviews, making junior engineers afraid to submit PRs. Team morale was suffering.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you worked with a difficult colleague.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I was paired with a senior engineer on Facebook's Integrity team for a critical misinformation detection project. He was brilliant but had driven two previous partners off the project with dismissive behavior. Within the first week, he rejected three of my design proposals with one-line responses like 'won't work' without explanation.

Task: I needed to find a way to collaborate effectively because the project was VP-visibility and avoiding him wasn't an option - we were the only two engineers assigned full-time.

Action: I observed his patterns instead of reacting emotionally. He respected engineers who showed depth, not breadth. I changed my approach: instead of polished proposals, I'd share my reasoning - 'here are 3 approaches I evaluated, here's why I'm leaning toward option 2, what am I missing?' I discovered he was most responsive between 6-8am, so I shifted my hours to overlap. When he was dismissive, I'd follow up in person asking specifically what wouldn't work. I also gave him credit publicly when his feedback improved my designs.

Result: By week 4, we were operating smoothly. He started proactively reviewing my code and suggesting optimizations. We delivered the misinformation classifier 2 weeks early with 94% precision - it blocked 2M pieces of misinfo in the first month. In my perf review, he specifically mentioned me as 'one of the few engineers who handles feedback well.' He requested me for his next project on coordinated inauthentic behavior detection.

description: You disagreed with your manager's decision, direction, or approach. Requires courage to push back respectfully while maintaining the relationship.
example_situation: Manager wanted to ship the feature without writing tests to meet the deadline. I believed this would create more problems and pushed back on the quality compromise.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you disagreed with your manager.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: My manager wanted our Ads Ranking team to adopt a new ML platform that leadership was pushing org-wide. I had evaluated it and found it would increase model training time by 3x and didn't support our custom feature engineering pipeline. My manager said we needed to align with the org direction.

Task: I needed to find a way to address my concerns without damaging my relationship with my manager or appearing resistant to org initiatives.

Action: I documented my concerns with data: training time impact on experimentation velocity (we'd go from 10 experiments/week to 3), migration effort (6 weeks), and the feature engineering gap. But I also proposed alternatives: 1) adopt the new platform for new models only while keeping existing models on current infra, 2) work with the platform team to add our feature engineering support, or 3) get a time-limited exception with commitment to migrate later. I presented this to my manager as 'I want to support the org direction, here's what I'd need to make it work' and offered to lead the platform team discussions myself.

Result: My manager appreciated the structured approach. I met with the platform team - they were receptive since other Ads teams had similar needs. We collaborated on adding feature engineering support over 8 weeks. We were the fifth team to migrate but had zero experimentation velocity regression. My manager mentioned in my review that she valued my 'disagree and commit with constructive proposals' approach.

description: Stakeholders continuously add requirements mid-project, causing team frustration and timeline risk. Requires setting boundaries while maintaining relationships.
example_situation: PM kept adding 'small' features mid-sprint saying they were easy. Team was working overtime and morale was dropping. No one wanted to push back directly.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to manage scope creep.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: We were 3 weeks into a 6-week project to rebuild Instagram's Explore recommendation UI when the PM started adding requirements: real-time personalization (original was batch), video preview on hover, and cross-posting to Facebook. Each 'small addition' was threatening to turn 6 weeks into 14 weeks.

Task: I needed to protect the team's ability to deliver while maintaining a good relationship with the PM and meeting actual business needs.

Action: I called a scope checkpoint meeting with the PM and my manager. I prepared a visual: original scope, added requests, and engineering estimates for each. I didn't say 'no' - I asked 'help me understand which are must-have for launch vs fast-follows.' I showed the math: adding everything meant missing the Q3 goal and the Explore redesign that execs had committed to externally. I proposed launching core UI on time, then real-time personalization in v2 (it needed backend changes anyway).

Result: PM agreed video preview and cross-posting could wait. We kept real-time personalization but scoped it to top 20% of users initially. Launched on schedule for Q3. Real-time for all users shipped 5 weeks later. Explore engagement increased 12% post-launch. PM thanked me for 'forcing the hard conversation' - she'd been getting pressure from multiple stakeholders and needed help prioritizing. We now do scope checkpoints at week 2 for all projects.

description: Customer demands or sales promises conflict with engineering reality, timelines, or best practices. Requires balancing customer satisfaction with sustainable engineering.
example_situation: Sales promised a custom feature to close a $2M deal with a 4-week timeline. Engineering estimated 12 weeks minimum. Customer was threatening to walk.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to balance customer needs with engineering constraints.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A major advertiser spending $50M/year threatened to move budget to Google unless we gave them custom audience targeting that bypassed our standard privacy controls. The sales team was pushing hard. Engineering knew this would violate our data use principles and potentially create regulatory issues.

Task: I needed to find a way to meet the advertiser's underlying need without compromising our integrity standards or setting a precedent of custom exceptions.

Action: I asked to join the advertiser call to understand their actual need, not just their request. They didn't want to bypass privacy - they wanted to reach users who had purchased from them before. Our standard tools required 1000+ user minimum for privacy; they had 800 users in a high-value segment. I proposed a solution: we'd build an aggregated lookalike audience feature that could find similar users while maintaining k-anonymity. This gave them reach to their target demographic without exposing individual users. I built a prototype in a week to demonstrate feasibility.

Result: Advertiser was happy - the lookalike audience actually performed better than their original request (3.2x ROAS vs their benchmark). We productized the feature in 6 weeks. It's now used by 200+ advertisers generating $30M in incremental revenue annually. Privacy team used this as a case study of 'finding yes' within constraints. I was recognized in the Integrity team's quarterly awards.

description: Failed to deliver a project, feature, or milestone on time. May have impacted customers, partners, or business commitments. Requires honest reflection on root causes.
example_situation: We promised a Q3 launch to a major partner who planned their marketing around it. We shipped 6 weeks late, damaging the relationship and costing potential revenue.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you missed a deadline.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I committed to delivering Facebook's new video monetization system for creators in 8 weeks for a major creator event. At week 6, we were only 50% done. I had underestimated the complexity of integrating with the existing ad serving pipeline and the payment compliance requirements across 40 countries.

Task: I needed to communicate the miss immediately, minimize impact on the creator event, and understand what went wrong in my estimation.

Action: The moment I realized we'd miss, I told my manager and the creator partnerships team that same day - no waiting, no hoping we could catch up. I came with a revised estimate (12 weeks) and breakdown of what caused the miss. I proposed a partial launch: we could deliver US-only monetization by week 8 (meeting the event minimum since most attending creators were US-based), with international rollout by week 12. I also started a pre-mortem while the project was still running, documenting lessons learned. My key mistake: estimating based on similar projects without accounting for the 40-country compliance requirement.

Result: Creator partnerships appreciated the early warning and accepted phased approach. Launched US monetization at week 8.5 for the event - creators earned $2M in the first month. Full international rollout completed at week 11. The pre-mortem led to a new estimation practice: we now require explicit 'compliance/legal complexity' and 'integration dependency' assessments for any estimate. My manager said the way I handled the miss mattered more than the miss itself.

description: Your code, decision, or oversight caused or contributed to a bug, outage, or degradation in production. Requires accountability and focus on learning/prevention.
example_situation: My code change had an edge case that caused a 2-hour outage affecting 50K users. I hadn't tested the specific scenario that triggered the bug.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you caused a production issue.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I deployed a caching optimization to Instagram's Story viewing service that I'd tested thoroughly in staging. Within an hour, memory usage spiked and we had cascading failures. 12% of users couldn't view Stories for 45 minutes. I had missed a memory leak in the cache eviction logic that only manifested under production's access patterns - staging had 1/100th the traffic diversity.

Task: I needed to fix the immediate issue, take full accountability, and ensure this class of problem couldn't happen again.

Action: First, I rolled back immediately rather than debugging in production. Then I owned the incident response - wrote the user comms, led the war room, and stayed until fully stable. In the post-mortem, I didn't deflect to staging limitations. I identified that I'd only tested with synthetic load patterns, not replayed production traffic. I proposed two changes: 1) add production traffic replay to our pre-deploy checklist, and 2) implement canary deployments for Stories infrastructure so future issues affect 1% of traffic, not 100%. I built the traffic replay tool myself over the next 2 weeks.

Result: Traffic replay tool caught 4 issues in other engineers' code in its first month. Canary deployments became standard for all Instagram latency-sensitive services. I presented the post-mortem at Engineering All-Hands as a learning opportunity. The VP of Engineering mentioned it as an example of 'owning failures and turning them into organizational improvements.' I was promoted 6 months later with this incident response cited positively.

description: Chose an architecture, technology, or approach that turned out to be wrong. Required revisiting the decision and potentially significant rework.
example_situation: I championed using a NoSQL database for its flexibility. 6 months later we hit query limitations and had to migrate to PostgreSQL, costing 3 months of engineering time.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you made a wrong technical decision.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I chose to build WhatsApp's internal analytics pipeline using a trendy stream processing framework because I was excited about the technology and it had impressive benchmarks. Eight months later, we had constant stability issues, poor documentation, and I was the only person who could debug it. I'd prioritized interesting technology over boring-but-reliable alternatives.

Task: I needed to acknowledge the mistake, propose a path forward that didn't waste the 8 months invested, and prevent similar decisions in the future.

Action: I wrote a technical decision review document acknowledging the choice was wrong and why - I'd optimized for technical elegance over operational simplicity. I quantified the costs: 4 hours/week of my time debugging, team reluctant to modify the pipeline, blocked hiring because candidates didn't know this niche framework. I proposed migration to Kafka + Flink (industry standard), with an incremental plan to migrate while keeping the pipeline running. I committed to leading the migration myself since it was my mistake to fix. I also proposed a new 'technology decision checklist' including 'who else can maintain this?' and 'what's the hiring pool?'

Result: Migration took 5 months alongside regular work. Within a month of completion, 4 engineers could debug and modify the pipeline. On-call pages dropped 80%. We hired 2 engineers who specifically mentioned the modern, standard stack. The technology decision checklist was adopted org-wide after I presented the case study to WhatsApp engineering leadership.

description: Failed to communicate clearly with stakeholders, teammates, or other teams, leading to wasted work, misaligned expectations, or conflict.
example_situation: I assumed PM wanted the feature to work one way based on a brief conversation. Built it over 2 weeks, then learned it was completely wrong. Had to rebuild from scratch.
typical_question: Tell me about a time miscommunication caused problems.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I told the Oculus partnerships team their SDK integration would be 'done by end of quarter.' I meant code complete and in internal testing. They heard it would be available to developers. They announced the SDK at a developer conference. When it wasn't publicly available by their expected date, they were embarrassed in front of their developer community.

Task: I needed to repair the relationship, deliver as fast as possible, and fix my communication practices permanently.

Action: I called their lead immediately - not Slack, not email - and apologized without excuses. I explained the disconnect and committed to public availability within 2 weeks. I personally worked through 3 weekends to expedite our security review and documentation. After things stabilized, I proposed a new practice: for any cross-team commitment, we explicitly specify 'code complete,' 'internal testing,' 'external beta,' or 'GA' with dates for each milestone. I documented this in a one-pager and shared with all teams I work with.

Result: SDK went public in 11 days. Partnerships relationship recovered - their lead said 'the response to the problem mattered more than the problem.' The explicit milestone practice was adopted across all of Reality Labs engineering after I presented at an engineering leads meeting. I now have a personal rule: any date commitment gets a written follow-up specifying exactly what 'done' means at each stage.

description: Significantly underestimated the complexity, scope, dependencies, or timeline of a project. Led to missed commitments or scrambling to deliver.
example_situation: I told the PM it would take 2 weeks based on my initial assessment. Didn't account for legacy system integration. Actually took 2 months.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you underestimated a project.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I estimated 3 weeks to add GDPR data export functionality to Facebook - 'just a database query and download UI.' It actually took 10 weeks because I'd ignored data scattered across 14 services, PII redaction requirements for different data types, legal review of export formats for each EU country, and load testing for potentially millions of simultaneous requests.

Task: I needed to understand why my estimate was so catastrophically wrong and build better practices.

Action: After delivery, I did a detailed estimation post-mortem. I'd estimated the happy path only. I created a checklist for future estimates: 1) Map ALL data sources involved, 2) Identify compliance/legal touchpoints, 3) List every team that needs to review, 4) Consider scale/load implications, 5) Add 50% buffer for cross-team dependencies. I also started 'estimation reviews' where I'd ask a senior engineer to challenge my assumptions before committing. I shared my checklist and the GDPR case study with my team.

Result: My next 5 projects all delivered within 15% of estimates. The estimation checklist was adopted by our entire product area and reduced re-estimation rate by 45%. I now lead estimation workshops for new engineers joining Facebook, using GDPR as the canonical example of 'what can go wrong.'

description: A team you led, managed, or were a key member of failed to deliver, meet quality standards, or achieve goals. Requires reflecting on your role in the outcome.
example_situation: The feature my team shipped had 3x the bug rate of other teams. Customers complained and we spent weeks firefighting instead of building new things.
typical_question: Tell me about a time your team failed to deliver.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: My team of 6 committed to rebuilding Messenger's notification system in one quarter. After 3 months, we'd only completed 40%. Morale was low, we'd accumulated significant technical debt rushing to show progress, and team members were starting to blame each other for the delays.

Task: As the tech lead, I needed to acknowledge my role in the failure, get us back on track, and rebuild team cohesion.

Action: I called a team offsite - no laptops, just discussion. I started by owning that as tech lead, the failure was mine first. I'd let us commit to an unrealistic scope without pushing back. We mapped what went wrong together: I found we had no clear definition of 'done' for each component, people were working on different assumptions, and I hadn't caught the coordination problems early. We agreed to reset: pick the 3 most critical components, define explicit acceptance criteria, and ship those in 6 weeks. I implemented daily 15-minute syncs and weekly demos so everyone could see progress.

Result: We shipped the 3 core components in 6 weeks. Team morale recovered as people saw tangible progress. Full system completed 2 months later (5 months total vs original 3-month estimate). Notification delivery latency improved 40%. The 'definition of done' practice became standard on our team. I now require explicit scope and acceptance criteria before any project kickoff.

description: Your actions or decisions damaged trust with a stakeholder, manager, teammate, or customer. Requires rebuilding credibility through consistent behavior.
example_situation: I overpromised to the VP about what we could deliver in Q4. When we fell short, he stopped trusting my estimates and started micromanaging the team.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you lost someone's trust.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I promised my director I'd flag any risks to our Ads measurement launch early. Then I didn't tell her about a critical blocker for 3 weeks because I thought I could solve it myself. When the launch slipped, she discovered I'd known about the risk. She removed me from the project update meetings and started requiring daily written status reports.

Task: I needed to rebuild her trust through consistent actions, not just apologies.

Action: I apologized specifically - not 'sorry for the miscommunication' but 'I broke my commitment to flag risks early, and that's on me.' I asked what I could do to rebuild trust. She said she needed full visibility into blockers and progress. I proposed daily Slack updates with: yesterday's progress, today's focus, and any blockers (even small ones). I committed to 90 days with no exceptions. I also proactively flagged 3 minor risks in the next two weeks that turned out to be nothing - better to over-communicate while rebuilding trust.

Result: After 60 days of consistent updates, she invited me back to project update meetings. After 90 days, she said the updates were so useful she asked other tech leads to adopt them. We've worked together on 5 more launches with no trust issues. She later sponsored my promotion, citing 'exceptional transparency and reliability.' I learned that transparency is a daily practice, not a one-time commitment.

description: Made a poor hiring decision or failed to address a bad hire quickly enough. Impact on team productivity, morale, or culture.
example_situation: I hired an engineer who interviewed well but couldn't deliver independently. I waited too long to address it, and the team had to carry their workload for 6 months.
typical_question: Tell me about a hiring mistake you made.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I hired a senior engineer for Instagram's Ads team based on exceptional technical interview performance. Within 3 months, it was clear he couldn't collaborate - he'd rewrite teammates' code without discussion, skip code reviews, and argue dismissively with junior engineers. One engineer asked to transfer teams, and others were avoiding working with him.

Task: I needed to address the situation fairly while protecting the team, and learn from my hiring mistake.

Action: First, I gave him direct, specific feedback with examples: 'In yesterday's code review, you rewrote Sarah's caching implementation without discussing why. She had good reasons for her approach, and rewriting without discussion made her feel her contribution wasn't valued.' I set clear expectations with a 30-day improvement plan focused on specific behaviors. He improved slightly but the core pattern remained. I involved HR and my manager, documented everything, and made the decision to part ways. For myself, I analyzed why I'd missed this: I'd focused entirely on technical signals. I proposed adding behavioral interview questions to our loop and making 'collaboration signal' a required debrief discussion.

Result: Team morale recovered within a month. The engineer I'd worried about losing decided to stay. Our revised interview process has helped us explicitly reject 3 technically strong candidates who showed similar collaboration red flags. I now weight collaboration signals equal to technical skills and always include team lunch or pairing session in senior interviews.

description: Identified and fixed a problem, improved a process, or enhanced a system without being asked to do so.
example_situation: Noticed our deploy pipeline was slow and error-prone. No one asked me to fix it, but I spent 20% time over a month to improve it, cutting deploy time by 60%.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you took initiative.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I noticed Instagram's iOS build took 45 minutes, and engineers were complaining but it wasn't on any roadmap. We did 15+ builds per engineer per day during active development. Quick math: 45 minutes x 15 builds x 100 engineers = 1,125 engineer-hours lost daily to waiting.

Task: Nobody asked me to fix this - it was 'just how things were.' But I saw an opportunity to recover massive engineering productivity.

Action: I spent three evenings profiling the build to understand bottlenecks. Found 60% of time was spent on unchanged modules being recompiled. I wrote a proposal showing the productivity math and asked my manager for 2 weeks to build a proof of concept for incremental builds. I scoped it tightly: cache and skip unchanged modules. I involved the iOS platform team to make sure my solution wouldn't conflict with their roadmap. I documented everything so it wouldn't become a black box.

Result: Build time dropped from 45 minutes to 12 minutes. Over 6 months, we recovered an estimated 50,000+ engineering hours. The solution was adopted by Facebook and WhatsApp iOS teams. My manager nominated this for a Meta-wide engineering excellence award, which it won. I was asked to lead a broader 'developer productivity' initiative based on this work.

description: Took full ownership of a feature or project from initial conception through production and monitoring.
example_situation: Owned entire search feature end-to-end: wrote the design doc, got stakeholder alignment, built it, wrote tests, deployed, set up monitoring, and oncall.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you owned something end-to-end.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Meta decided to launch Instagram Shopping in Brazil - our first expansion to South America. This touched payments (new processors, currency), tax compliance (nota fiscal requirements), seller onboarding (Portuguese localization), and logistics integrations. No one wanted to own it because it crossed 6 teams.

Task: I volunteered to own the entire Brazil launch end-to-end, even though it was far outside my team's normal scope.

Action: I mapped every system that needed changes - 18 services across 8 teams. I created a master project tracker with each team's deliverables, dependencies, and deadlines. I scheduled weekly syncs with each team lead and escalated blockers within 24 hours. I did the unglamorous work myself: wrote the tax calculation logic, created Portuguese seller help content, and built the nota fiscal integration when that team was overloaded. When legal had questions about Brazilian consumer protection requirements, I was the single technical point of contact. I also set up the Brazil-specific monitoring dashboards and oncall runbooks.

Result: Launched Instagram Shopping Brazil on schedule - the only international launch that quarter to hit its date. 50,000 sellers onboarded in the first month, $10M GMV in first quarter. Zero compliance issues in 18 months. The project framework I created became Meta's template for new market launches. I was promoted to senior with this project cited as primary evidence of operating at staff level scope.

description: Took accountability when something went wrong rather than blaming circumstances or others.
example_situation: My change caused a production incident. I immediately owned it in the incident channel, led the fix, wrote the postmortem, and implemented prevention measures.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you took responsibility for a failure.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A feature I'd code reviewed and approved caused a bug that sent duplicate notifications to 5 million Facebook users - some received 20+ copies of the same notification. The junior engineer who wrote the code was panicking. The bug was actually in edge case handling that I should have caught in review.

Task: I needed to own the situation, fix it quickly, and make sure the junior engineer didn't lose confidence.

Action: I immediately posted in the incident channel: 'I approved this code review and missed the edge case - this is on me.' I led the incident response: identified all affected users, built the deduplication query, and wrote the user apology notification. I didn't let the junior engineer take any blame publicly. Privately, I walked through the bug with her as a learning opportunity, showing her what I should have caught and how to test for it. I then proposed adding automated tests for notification edge cases and a checklist for notification code reviews.

Result: Duplicate notifications stopped within 2 hours. We received minimal user complaints because of proactive communication. The junior engineer's confidence was preserved - she's now a strong senior engineer who mentors others on notification systems. The notification test suite I proposed has caught 6 similar bugs before production. My manager said my handling demonstrated 'senior engineering leadership in crisis.'

description: Contributed beyond your formal job responsibilities to help the team or company succeed.
example_situation: As an engineer, I noticed we didn't have clear product specs. Started writing them myself, conducting user interviews, and helping PM prioritize based on customer pain.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you went beyond your job description.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A critical API powering WhatsApp Business was failing intermittently during peak hours. It was owned by another team whose tech lead was on paternity leave. Their remaining engineers were underwater with other fires, and the API failures were causing business customers to miss messages - directly impacting WhatsApp's B2B revenue.

Task: It wasn't my team's responsibility, but I had context on that codebase from a previous project and saw a chance to help.

Action: I asked my manager for 3 days to investigate. I found the root cause: a connection pool exhaustion issue that only manifested when traffic exceeded 10K requests/second - which happened during business hours in Asian markets. I wrote a detailed bug report with the fix, offered to implement it myself, and submitted the PR. I also added monitoring that would alert at 8K requests/second so the team would have warning. I documented everything so their team could maintain it without me.

Result: Fixed the bug that had been causing issues for 4 weeks. Business customer complaints dropped 90% immediately. When the tech lead returned from leave, he had a clean handoff document and monitoring in place. My manager mentioned this in my perf review as an example of 'Meta-level ownership.' The WhatsApp Business team now invites me to their design reviews, and we help each other regularly.

description: Made decisions or investments that prioritized long-term health over short-term speed or convenience.
example_situation: Pushed for a refactor that would slow us down for a sprint but prevent increasing tech debt. Team resisted at first but it paid off in velocity 3 months later.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you prioritized long-term over short-term.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: We had pressure to ship Reels' duet feature fast using TikTok's exact UX patterns - 2 weeks to copy their approach. Building a more flexible system that could support future collaborative video formats (stitch, remix, react) would take 6 weeks. My manager was pushing for the quick option to hit a quarterly goal.

Task: I believed the 2-week solution would require complete rebuilds for each future format, but I needed to make the case with data.

Action: I analyzed our product roadmap and found 3 more collaborative formats planned for the next year. I modeled both scenarios: quick approach would mean 2 weeks now + 4 weeks each for the next 3 formats = 14 weeks total. Flexible system would mean 6 weeks now + 1 week each for future formats = 9 weeks total, plus easier A/B testing. I proposed a hybrid: build the flexible foundation but only implement duet initially to hit quarterly goal (4 weeks). I committed to having stitch ready within 2 weeks of duet launch to prove the extensibility.

Result: Shipped duet in 4 weeks, hitting quarterly goal. Stitch shipped 2 weeks later - the PM had originally estimated 6 weeks for stitch alone. React format shipped in 1 week. The flexible architecture saved an estimated 8 engineering weeks over the year and enabled faster experimentation. My manager said this was a good example of 'yes, and' thinking - meeting short-term commitments while protecting long-term velocity.

description: Made decisions with customer impact as the primary consideration, even when it meant more work or internal pushback.
example_situation: PM wanted to deprioritize accessibility features. I advocated for keeping them, showing data on impacted users. Extra work but right thing for customers.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you advocated for customers.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our product team wanted to remove Facebook's 'Download Your Data' feature from the settings menu because only 2% of users used it and it was expensive to maintain. I noticed that 2% represented 40 million people, and the feature was essential for users trying to leave abusive relationships, journalists protecting sources, and people in countries with government surveillance.

Task: I needed to advocate for keeping the feature by connecting our internal efficiency goals to real customer impact.

Action: I pulled usage data segmented by region and use case. Found that usage spiked 300% in countries during political crises, and support tickets showed the feature was literally helping people escape dangerous situations. I talked to our Trust & Safety team who confirmed this data. I presented to the product team with specific user stories (anonymized) showing the human impact. I also proposed a middle ground: move the feature deeper in settings (reducing maintenance surface) rather than removing it entirely, and add better rate limiting to reduce infrastructure costs.

Result: Product team kept the feature with the modified placement. One month later, usage spiked during political unrest in Myanmar - we helped tens of thousands of users export their data before potential government crackdowns. The user story research became part of our 'customer impact review' for any deprecation decision. I was invited to join the Privacy team's advisory group based on this work.

description: Held yourself or your team accountable to commitments, quality standards, or goals you set.
example_situation: Committed to weekly releases to improve feedback cycles. Made it happen for 6 months straight, even when it was hard. Team learned to scope work appropriately.
typical_question: Tell me about how you hold yourself accountable.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I set a team OKR to reduce Instagram Feed's p99 latency from 800ms to 200ms. At end of quarter, we were at 400ms. I had been overconfident in my technical approach and hadn't course-corrected when early results showed we were off track.

Task: I needed to own the miss transparently and understand what I should have done differently.

Action: In our quarterly review, I didn't blame external factors like the iOS 15 launch that added complexity. I presented: 'We missed the target. Here's what I got wrong.' I'd focused on one optimization approach (caching) for 8 weeks before realizing it had diminishing returns - I should have run parallel experiments earlier. I also hadn't set monthly checkpoints; we discovered we were off track too late to pivot. I proposed a new approach for next quarter: weekly progress check-ins against a latency curve, 3 parallel optimization tracks, and kill criteria for any track not showing results by week 4.

Result: Next quarter we hit 180ms - exceeding the original goal. The weekly checkpoint practice was adopted by 4 other teams in the org. My director appreciated the accountability: 'Anyone can own success; owning failures and fixing the process is what builds trust.' I now set explicit monthly milestones for all OKRs with 'are we on track?' reviews.

description: Anticipated problems or needs before they became urgent and took proactive action to address them.
example_situation: Saw that our database would hit capacity limits in 6 months based on growth trends. Started the migration project early, finished smoothly before it became a crisis.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you anticipated a problem.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I noticed WhatsApp's media storage was growing at 25% monthly but no one was monitoring projected capacity. At that rate, we'd hit storage limits in 7 months. This wasn't on anyone's radar because 7 months felt far away, but our procurement process for storage infrastructure took 5 months, and migration testing would need 2 months.

Task: I decided to raise the issue early even though it wasn't urgent, because by the time it was urgent, it would be too late.

Action: I built a projection model showing when we'd hit thresholds: 70% capacity (alert), 85% (critical), 100% (outage affecting 2 billion users). I mapped the timeline backwards: procurement (5 months) + migration (2 months) + buffer (1 month) = we needed to start in 1 month, not 7. I presented to my manager and infrastructure lead with the timeline and recommended actions. I proposed starting procurement immediately and volunteered to lead capacity planning. I also built monitoring to track growth rate changes weekly in case my projections were wrong.

Result: Started procurement 6 months before we would have hit limits. New storage capacity arrived with 6 weeks to spare. When growth actually exceeded my projections due to a viral video trend, we had headroom. The infrastructure lead said my early warning prevented what would have been a massive incident affecting billions of users. I now do quarterly 'what's growing' reviews for all systems I own, and this practice has been adopted across WhatsApp infrastructure.

description: Helped a junior engineer, new hire, or struggling teammate grow their skills and become more effective.
example_situation: Mentored a new grad who was struggling with code quality and confidence. Pair programmed weekly, gave constructive feedback. Now they're a strong mid-level engineer.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you mentored someone.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A junior engineer on the Facebook Ads team was technically capable but struggled in code reviews - she'd either accept all feedback without understanding or get defensive and argue every point. Her growth had stalled, she was frustrated, and senior engineers were avoiding reviewing her code.

Task: I took on mentoring her to develop her code review skills and professional communication.

Action: I started 'paired code reviews' - we'd review the same PR separately, then compare our feedback and discuss differences. This showed her what experienced engineers look for and why. When she got defensive, I helped her reframe: 'They're not attacking you; they're improving the code. Try asking: Can you help me understand why you prefer approach X?' I also taught her to separate style preferences from correctness issues. We met weekly for 4 months, and I gave her increasing responsibility - first reviewing my code, then other juniors' code.

Result: Within 5 months, she was doing independent reviews that senior engineers trusted. Her review comments became specific and constructive. She's now a senior engineer who other juniors specifically request as a reviewer. She thanked me in her promotion announcement. This experience taught me that technical skills are often not the blocker - communication and confidence are.

description: Proposed, championed, and drove adoption of a new tool, process, practice, or technology without having formal authority.
example_situation: Proposed adopting a new testing framework after seeing too many production bugs. Built proof of concept, presented benefits, got buy-in, led the migration.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you drove an initiative.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Meta had no consistent approach to API documentation across products - Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp all had different formats, different tools, none auto-generated from code. External developers complained constantly, and internal teams wasted hours answering questions that docs should answer.

Task: I proposed and drove a unified API documentation initiative from zero to adoption across all three products.

Action: I wrote a proposal with goals (single doc format, auto-generated from code annotations, 80% developer satisfaction), resource needs (my 20% time + 2 volunteer engineers), and a rollout plan. I built a proof of concept using OpenAPI spec generation from our code annotations. I recruited 4 engineers across products who were frustrated with the current state. For teams resistant to change, I offered to do the initial migration myself - they'd just review. I handled logistics: set up the doc infrastructure, created annotation templates, and wrote a migration guide. I presented weekly progress to an executive sponsor I'd recruited.

Result: Launched unified docs covering 400+ API endpoints across all three products. Developer satisfaction went from 45% to 82% in 6 months. Support tickets about API usage dropped 60%. The initiative won an internal infrastructure award. I handed off maintenance to a newly formed Developer Experience team after establishing the process. This work was cited in my promotion to senior.

description: Convinced stakeholders, leadership, or peers to change direction or adopt your recommendation on an important decision.
example_situation: Team was about to launch with a critical security flaw. I escalated, presented the risk clearly to leadership, and convinced them to delay launch by 2 weeks.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you influenced a decision.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Leadership decided to rewrite the entire Instagram backend in a new language because it was 'the future of Meta infrastructure.' I believed this was a mistake - the rewrite would take 2+ years and our current backend wasn't the problem; our service architecture was. The real issues (latency, reliability) wouldn't be solved by a language change.

Task: I needed to influence a VP-level decision without formal authority and without appearing resistant to org direction.

Action: I didn't argue against the rewrite directly. Instead, I asked leadership what problems they were trying to solve. They said: slow development velocity, scaling issues, hiring challenges. I agreed these were real. I then analyzed whether the rewrite would actually solve them - and found it wouldn't address the architectural issues causing latency. I proposed an alternative: modular decomposition of our highest-latency services, which could be done in any language. I built a prototype showing we could fix the worst latency issue in 6 weeks instead of 24 months. I presented as 'a faster path to the same goals,' not 'you're wrong.'

Result: Leadership agreed to try the modular approach first. We fixed the latency issues in 4 months. The full rewrite was indefinitely postponed - we eventually adopted the new language for new services only. The VP later mentioned my 'data-driven alternative proposal' as exactly what they need from senior engineers. I was asked to join the architecture review board based on this work.

description: Brought together people with different perspectives or conflicting interests to reach agreement and move forward.
example_situation: Three teams had conflicting requirements for a shared platform. Facilitated workshops to understand each team's needs, found common ground, built solution all could accept.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you built consensus.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Three teams at WhatsApp had different requirements for our new message storage system: Messages team wanted maximum write throughput, Search team wanted complex query support, and Backup team wanted cheap cold storage. Each was advocating strongly for their preference, and the discussions were going in circles.

Task: As the storage infrastructure lead, I needed to drive a decision all teams could support.

Action: I reframed the discussion from 'which design' to 'what requirements matter most.' I facilitated a session where we listed all requirements and had each team score importance 1-5. We agreed on weights before discussing any solutions. Then I evaluated 4 architectural options against our weighted requirements with input from each team. The scoring revealed: write throughput and query support were both critical, cold storage was important but not blocking. I proposed a tiered architecture: hot tier optimized for writes (Messages happy), warm tier with query indexes (Search happy), cold tier for old messages (Backup happy). Each team got their top priority.

Result: All three teams accepted the tiered approach because they'd participated in defining success criteria. Implementation went smoothly with no sabotage. The requirements-first framework became our standard for cross-team platform decisions. One team lead said 'I didn't get everything I wanted but I understand why, and I trust the process.'

description: Defined strategy, roadmap, or technical direction for a team or project that guided others' work.
example_situation: Created 6-month technical roadmap for the platform team. Defined priorities, sequencing, and success metrics. Team used it to make daily decisions.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you set direction.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram's API team had no consistent standards - every service had different authentication patterns, error formats, rate limiting approaches, and versioning strategies. New engineers were confused, and every code review became a style debate. External developers integrating with us complained about inconsistency.

Task: I decided to establish API standards for Instagram that would guide all current and future development.

Action: I researched industry best practices and audited our existing APIs. I wrote an RFC proposing: consistent authentication (OAuth 2.0), standard error format (RFC 7807), unified rate limiting with clear headers, and semantic versioning. I circulated for feedback for 3 weeks, held office hours, and incorporated suggestions - several engineers raised valid edge cases I'd missed. I addressed concerns 1:1 rather than in large meetings where people might be defensive. I committed to migrating two of my own APIs first as reference implementations.

Result: RFC approved with team consensus after 4 weeks of iteration. I migrated my APIs in 3 weeks as the reference. Over 6 months, the team standardized all public APIs. Code review discussions shifted from style to substance. New engineer onboarding time for API work dropped 50%. Three other product teams adopted our standards. External developer satisfaction with our APIs increased from 3.2 to 4.4 out of 5.

description: Improved team practices, quality standards, code quality, or engineering culture to make everyone more effective.
example_situation: Introduced code review guidelines and quality checklists. Bug rate dropped 30%, and reviews became more consistent and less contentious.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you raised the bar for your team.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our Facebook Marketplace team's code quality was inconsistent - some engineers wrote comprehensive tests, others wrote none. Code reviews were rubber stamps. We were shipping bugs that basic testing would have caught, spending 30% of our time on bug fixes instead of new features.

Task: I wanted to establish testing as a non-negotiable standard, not just a nice-to-have.

Action: First, I made sure I was the example - I wrote comprehensive tests for all my code and pointed to them in reviews. I proposed a concrete standard: 80% coverage for new code, no PR merged without tests for changed logic, integration tests required for any user-facing flow. To make this achievable, I wrote testing utilities that made common Marketplace patterns easy to test in 5 lines instead of 50. I offered to pair with anyone struggling. In code reviews, I consistently asked 'how is this tested?' rather than just approving. I tracked and shared metrics monthly on test coverage and bug escape rate.

Result: Coverage went from 35% to 88% over 5 months. Production bugs dropped 65%. Initially there was grumbling about slower velocity, but when we stopped having weekly fire drills, the team embraced it. Two engineers told me they'd learned to value testing because of this experience. The testing utilities I built were adopted by 5 other Marketplace-adjacent teams. I was asked to present our testing transformation at an engineering all-hands.

description: Led, coordinated, or kept the team focused during an incident, crisis, outage, or high-pressure situation.
example_situation: Led the response during a 4-hour outage affecting all customers. Coordinated 6 engineers, kept stakeholders informed, and drove systematic debugging until resolution.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you led through a crisis.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: During Thanksgiving peak traffic, Facebook Marketplace's checkout system went down for 90 minutes. We were losing an estimated $500K per hour in GMV. Engineers were panicking, Slack had 5 different threads with conflicting information, and nobody knew who was doing what.

Task: As the senior engineer on-call, I needed to bring order to chaos and restore service as fast as possible.

Action: I took explicit command in the incident channel: 'I'm leading this incident. Please mute unless I ask for input.' I assigned clear roles: one engineer on rollback investigation, one on database queries, one on customer communications, one on load balancer logs. I created a single war room Zoom and archived other threads. Every 10 minutes I posted status to an exec channel so leadership wouldn't interrupt us. When we identified the cause (a caching bug triggered by a traffic spike pattern we'd never seen), I made the call to restart with 50% capacity rather than wait for the full fix - get revenue flowing, then fix properly.

Result: Restored service in 40 minutes at 50% capacity, full service at 90 minutes. Total revenue impact: $750K instead of the $3M+ it would have been at the original trajectory. The incident process I ran became Marketplace's template. I documented it and trained 8 other engineers on incident command. The VP of Commerce mentioned the response as 'exactly how incidents should be handled.' I was asked to lead incident commander training org-wide.

description: Made or advocated for a decision you knew would be unpopular but believed was right for the team or company.
example_situation: Recommended canceling a feature that the team had worked on for 2 months because user research showed no one wanted it. Team was upset but it was the right call.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you made an unpopular decision.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our Instagram team had a beloved 'hack week' where engineers could work on any project. But we'd missed commitments 3 quarters in a row, and stakeholders were frustrated. As tech lead, I believed we needed to pause hack week until we rebuilt credibility.

Task: I needed to make and communicate a decision I knew the team would strongly dislike.

Action: I didn't decide unilaterally. I shared the data with the team: we'd missed 8 of 12 quarterly commitments over the past year, and leadership was considering staffing changes. I explained the stakeholder feedback verbatim. I proposed pausing hack week for 2 quarters while we rebuilt trust, with a firm commitment to reinstate it once we hit 3 consecutive quarters of commitments. I also offered alternatives: protected 'innovation time' on Fridays (less disruptive) and a commitment to rotate 1 engineer per quarter to exploratory work. I was transparent that this was my recommendation and I understood the team disagreed.

Result: Team was disappointed but appreciated the transparency and the alternatives. We hit our commitments for 3 straight quarters. I reinstated hack week as promised. The team's trust in my leadership increased because I followed through on both the pause and the reinstatement. One engineer said 'I hated losing hack week but I respect that you were direct about why and kept your promise.' We've now hit commitments for 5 straight quarters while maintaining hack week.

description: Delivered a project or feature under extreme time pressure. Required focus, prioritization, and possibly cutting scope or working intensively.
example_situation: Had 2 weeks to build a critical feature for a major partner launch. Normal timeline would be 6 weeks. Failure meant losing a $5M deal.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to meet a tight deadline.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram needed to launch a 'Close Friends' sharing feature for Stories before a competitor's similar feature went public. We had 3 weeks instead of the normal 8-week timeline. Marketing had already briefed press with an embargo date.

Task: I needed to deliver a production-ready feature in 3 weeks that would normally take 8, without compromising user privacy or stability.

Action: I immediately mapped the critical path and identified what could be cut. Core sharing to a Close Friends list: must have. Editing the list from Stories: nice to have - we could launch with settings-only editing. I proposed this scope reduction to product, who agreed. I then parallelized work: I took the backend API and list management while another engineer handled the UI. We did daily 15-minute syncs instead of waiting for blockers. I made the call to use an existing notification system rather than build custom, accepting slightly slower delivery notifications. I also negotiated with QA for focused testing on the critical paths only, with broader testing post-launch.

Result: Launched 2 days before the embargo deadline. Feature was stable - zero P0 bugs in the first week. Close Friends became one of Instagram's most-used sharing features, with 40% of daily Story creators using it within 3 months. The editing-from-Stories feature shipped 3 weeks later as planned. My manager cited this as an example of 'smart scope management under pressure.'

description: Led or significantly contributed to a technically challenging project involving complex systems, scale, or novel problems.
example_situation: Built a real-time data pipeline handling 1M events per second with sub-100ms latency requirements. Required custom solutions as no off-the-shelf tools met our needs.
typical_question: Tell me about your most technically challenging project.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Facebook needed to rebuild the News Feed ranking system to support real-time personalization - updating what users see within seconds of their interactions, not hours. The existing batch system processed 500B interactions daily but with 6-hour latency. We needed sub-minute latency at the same scale.

Task: I was the tech lead responsible for designing and delivering a system that could process 500B daily events with sub-60-second end-to-end latency, while maintaining ranking quality.

Action: I spent 3 weeks prototyping different architectures. The key insight was that we didn't need real-time processing for ALL signals - only the high-value ones like recent likes and comments. I designed a hybrid system: a streaming layer for high-value signals (using Kafka + custom processors) feeding into the existing batch infrastructure. The hardest part was handling late-arriving data without double-counting. I invented a 'watermark reconciliation' approach that tracked which events had been processed in each system. I wrote the core streaming processor myself and coordinated 4 other engineers on the integration work. We ran shadow mode for 3 weeks, comparing outputs to the batch system.

Result: Launched to 100% of users after 4 months. Achieved 45-second median latency for high-value signals. Engagement metrics improved 2.3% because users saw more relevant content faster. The hybrid architecture became the template for 3 other ranking systems at Meta. I presented the design at an internal tech conference and was promoted to staff engineer with this project as the primary evidence.

description: Successfully delivered despite unclear, incomplete, or frequently changing requirements. Required making decisions with imperfect information.
example_situation: PM had only a rough idea of what customers wanted. Built MVP based on assumptions, gathered feedback weekly, and iterated. Final product was different from initial spec.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you delivered with unclear requirements.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Leadership asked my team to 'improve creator monetization on Reels' with no specific metrics, no defined features, and conflicting input from different stakeholders. Some wanted tipping, others wanted ad revenue sharing, others wanted brand partnerships. We had one quarter to show results.

Task: I needed to make progress and deliver value despite having no clear requirements or success criteria.

Action: Instead of waiting for clarity, I defined it myself. I interviewed 15 creators to understand their actual pain points - turns out most didn't care about new monetization methods; they wanted better analytics on their existing earnings. I proposed a 2-week sprint to build a creator earnings dashboard as an MVP. I set my own success metrics: 50% weekly active usage among monetizing creators. I built the MVP with one other engineer while continuing to gather feedback. When stakeholders pushed for tipping features, I showed them the creator interview data and proposed tipping as v2 after we validated the dashboard.

Result: Dashboard launched in 3 weeks with 67% weekly active usage - exceeding my target. Creator support tickets about earnings dropped 40%. Leadership appreciated that I'd 'found the real problem.' We built tipping in Q2, informed by dashboard usage data. My approach of 'define clarity when none exists' became a model for other ambiguous projects.

description: Delivered results with significantly constrained team size, budget, time, or tooling compared to what the project normally required.
example_situation: Had only 2 engineers to build a system that comparable companies staffed with teams of 8-10. Had to make smart trade-offs on scope and approach.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you delivered with limited resources.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: WhatsApp needed to build an enterprise API for businesses to send customer service messages, but we only had 2 engineers (including me) while competitors had teams of 10+. We had 4 months to launch or lose major enterprise customers to competitors.

Task: I needed to deliver a production-ready API with 2 engineers that would normally require 10, without cutting corners on reliability.

Action: I made ruthless prioritization decisions. Instead of building custom infrastructure, I leveraged existing WhatsApp message routing - this saved 2 months of work. I chose to support only the top 3 use cases (order confirmations, shipping updates, appointment reminders) instead of the 12 the PM wanted. I automated everything possible: deployment, testing, monitoring setup. I also made the controversial call to launch with rate limits that were lower than competitors, knowing we could increase them later. I documented extensively so we wouldn't lose knowledge if either of us left.

Result: Launched on time with 2 engineers. Signed 50 enterprise customers in the first quarter including 3 Fortune 500 companies. Revenue exceeded projections by 40%. We gradually expanded to all 12 use cases over the next year as we hired more engineers. The 'leverage existing infra' approach became a principle for new WhatsApp features.

description: Successfully worked with an old, poorly documented, or fragile codebase. Required patience, detective work, and careful changes.
example_situation: Had to add critical features to a 10-year-old system with no tests, no documentation, and the original authors long gone. Any change risked breaking everything.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you worked with a legacy system.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Facebook's photo storage system was 12 years old with no documentation, no tests, and the original authors had left. We needed to add support for HEIC format (iPhone's default) but any change risked corrupting billions of existing photos. The last engineer who tried to modify it caused a 3-hour outage.

Task: I volunteered to add HEIC support to a system everyone else was afraid to touch.

Action: I spent 3 weeks just reading code and mapping the system before writing any changes. I created documentation as I went - the first docs this system had in years. I identified the riskiest parts: a format detection function that used magic bytes in ways I didn't fully understand. Instead of modifying it, I added HEIC as a new code path that couldn't affect existing formats. I wrote comprehensive tests for my changes AND retroactively for the parts I touched. I set up a shadow pipeline that processed real uploads through my code without saving, comparing outputs to production for 2 weeks. I also created a rollback plan with specific metrics that would trigger automatic reversion.

Result: Launched HEIC support with zero incidents. My documentation became the onboarding guide for new engineers. The testing patterns I established were applied to other legacy systems. 6 months later, another engineer successfully added WebP support using my approach. My manager said this project demonstrated 'senior engineering judgment' in how I de-risked the work.

description: Coordinated work across multiple teams, possibly across time zones or organizations, to deliver a shared outcome.
example_situation: Aligned 4 teams across 3 time zones for a platform migration. Required weekly syncs, clear interfaces, and constant communication to stay on track.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you coordinated across multiple teams.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Meta was migrating all products to a new authentication system. For Instagram, this required coordinating iOS (Menlo Park), Android (NYC), Backend (London), and Security (Tel Aviv) - 4 teams across 4 time zones, none of whom reported to me.

Task: I was asked to coordinate the Instagram migration because I had relationships across all teams from previous projects.

Action: I created a single source of truth: a shared doc with every team's deliverables, dependencies, and blockers, updated daily. I scheduled one weekly sync at a time that worked for everyone (6am PT / 2pm London / 4pm Tel Aviv) and made it efficient - 25 minutes max with async pre-reads. For each team, I identified their biggest concern and addressed it: iOS worried about app size increase, so I worked with them on lazy loading; Backend worried about latency, so I ran benchmarks. When conflicts arose, I resolved them 1:1 before they became public disagreements. I also created a private Slack channel with all tech leads for fast escalation.

Result: Completed migration in 12 weeks, 2 weeks ahead of schedule. Zero user-facing incidents during cutover. This was the smoothest of all product migrations - Facebook and WhatsApp both had issues. My coordination approach was documented and used for subsequent cross-team projects. The Security team lead specifically thanked me for 'making them feel included despite the time zone.'

description: Worked on a project where failure would have significant business, customer, or safety impact. Required extra diligence and stress management.
example_situation: Built the payment processing system handling $10M in daily transactions. Any bug could mean lost money or regulatory issues. Zero tolerance for errors.
typical_question: Tell me about a high-stakes project you worked on.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I was responsible for rebuilding Facebook Pay's transaction reconciliation system. This system verified that $50M+ in daily transactions matched between our systems and payment processors. Any bug could mean users losing money or regulatory violations in 40 countries.

Task: I needed to rebuild the system to support new payment methods while maintaining 100% accuracy on financial reconciliation - there was zero tolerance for errors.

Action: I approached this with extreme caution. Before writing any code, I spent 2 weeks documenting every edge case in the existing system by reading years of incident reports. I implemented triple-redundancy: my new system, the old system, and an independent audit job all had to agree before any reconciliation was finalized. I wrote 400+ unit tests covering every currency, payment method, and edge case I'd documented. I ran parallel processing for 6 weeks, manually reviewing every discrepancy (there were 47, all explainable). I created runbooks for every possible failure scenario. I also insisted on a phased rollout: 1% of transactions for 2 weeks before increasing.

Result: Zero reconciliation errors in 18 months since launch. Successfully supported 3 new payment method launches. Passed regulatory audits in EU, US, and Brazil with no findings. The testing approach I developed became the standard for all financial systems at Meta. I was recognized with a 'financial integrity' award from the payments team.

description: Improved reliability, reduced incidents, or enhanced operational practices for a system or team.
example_situation: Reduced on-call pages by 70% by identifying recurring issues, fixing root causes, and adding better monitoring and runbooks.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you improved system reliability.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram's Direct Messaging service was paging on-call engineers 15-20 times per week. Engineers were burned out, and each page cost an average of 2 hours of investigation. Most pages were false alarms or known issues without runbooks.

Task: I volunteered to fix the operational health of DMs, even though it wasn't my team's system.

Action: I started with data: I categorized 3 months of pages by root cause. Found that 60% were false alarms from overly sensitive alerts, 25% were the same 5 recurring issues, and 15% were genuine novel problems. For false alarms, I tuned alert thresholds based on actual user impact, not arbitrary metrics. For recurring issues, I wrote runbooks and automated the most common fixes. For one issue that paged weekly, I fixed the underlying bug rather than just documenting the workaround. I also created a 'page review' process: every page got categorized and if we saw the same issue 3 times, we had to either fix it or document why we couldn't.

Result: On-call pages dropped from 18/week to 4/week within 2 months. Engineer satisfaction on the on-call survey improved from 2.1 to 4.2 out of 5. Mean time to resolution dropped 60% because of runbooks. The 'page review' process was adopted by 6 other Instagram teams. I was asked to present the approach at an infrastructure all-hands.

description: Found the root cause of a difficult, intermittent, or mysterious bug or performance problem. Required systematic investigation and persistence.
example_situation: Users reported intermittent failures that only happened in production under high load. Took 3 weeks of adding instrumentation and analyzing logs to find a race condition.
typical_question: Tell me about the hardest bug you had to debug.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram users reported that Stories occasionally showed a black screen instead of content, but only for about 0.1% of views. The issue had existed for months but nobody could reproduce it. It was affecting millions of Story views daily.

Task: I volunteered to investigate this bug that three other engineers had given up on.

Action: Since I could not reproduce it locally, I added extensive logging to production, tracking every step of the Story rendering pipeline. After 2 weeks of data collection, I noticed the failures correlated with specific device models and network conditions. I narrowed it down to a race condition: when a user had slow network and scrolled quickly, we would start loading Story B before Story A finished, and a shared buffer would get corrupted. The fix was not obvious because the buffer was designed to be thread safe, but there was a 3 millisecond window during buffer resize where it was not. I wrote a reproduction test that simulated the exact timing and confirmed the race condition.

Result: Fixed a bug that had affected 2 million Story views daily for 8 months. Black screen reports dropped to near zero. I documented the debugging methodology and presented it at an engineering lunch and learn. The systematic logging approach I developed was added to our debugging playbook for intermittent issues.

description: Designed a solution for a complex technical problem balancing requirements like scale, latency, cost, and maintainability.
example_situation: Designed a caching layer that reduced p99 latency from 800ms to 100ms while handling 10x traffic growth. Required careful invalidation strategy.
typical_question: Tell me about a complex system you designed.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Facebook Marketplace needed a new search ranking system that could personalize results for 1 billion users while maintaining sub 200ms latency. The existing system was one size fits all and our search conversion was 30% below competitors.

Task: I was responsible for designing a system that could serve personalized rankings at scale without blowing up our infrastructure costs.

Action: I explored three approaches: real time personalization (accurate but expensive), precomputed rankings (cheap but stale), and a hybrid. The key insight was that 80% of personalization value came from just 5 signals that changed slowly (location, price preference, category affinity). I designed a system with two layers: a precomputed layer that updated user preferences daily, and a lightweight real time layer that only adjusted for recency signals. I prototyped each approach with 1% of traffic to validate latency and relevance tradeoffs. I also designed the system to gracefully degrade if the real time layer failed, falling back to precomputed results.

Result: Launched to 100% of Marketplace users. Search conversion improved 18%, exceeding the 15% goal. P99 latency stayed under 150ms. Infrastructure costs were only 20% higher than the non personalized system, versus the 300% increase the pure real time approach would have required. The two layer architecture pattern was adopted by two other ranking systems at Meta.

description: Significantly improved performance, reduced costs, or increased efficiency of an existing system through analysis and targeted changes.
example_situation: Reduced our AWS bill by 40% ($200K annually) by analyzing query patterns, adding indexes, and rightsizing instances without impacting performance.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you optimized a system.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: WhatsApp's media transcoding service was costing $8M annually in compute, and costs were growing 20% per quarter as video messaging increased. Leadership asked if we could reduce costs without affecting user experience.

Task: I was assigned to find at least 20% cost savings in the transcoding pipeline.

Action: I started by profiling where compute time actually went. Found that 40% of transcoding jobs were for videos that were never viewed because users deleted messages before recipients opened them. I proposed a lazy transcoding approach: store the original video first and only transcode when the recipient actually opens the message. For the 60% that were viewed, I analyzed codec efficiency and found we were using conservative settings that produced larger files than necessary. I ran quality tests with 100 users comparing old and new settings, and nobody could tell the difference. I also identified that 15% of transcodings were duplicates because the same video was sent to multiple recipients.

Result: Total cost reduction of 45%, saving $3.6M annually. User experience metrics (video load time, quality ratings) were unchanged. The lazy transcoding pattern was adopted by Instagram for their video processing. I was recognized in the cost efficiency awards that quarter.

description: Used data, metrics, experiments, or analysis to drive a technical or product decision rather than relying on intuition.
example_situation: A/B tested two implementation approaches with 5% of traffic each. Approach B showed 15% better conversion and 20% lower latency. Data made the decision clear.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you used data to make a decision.
strong_hire_example:
