Situation: Our team was debating whether to rebuild Instagram's comment system from scratch or incrementally refactor it. The tech lead favored a full rebuild for cleaner architecture. I was skeptical it was worth the 6 month investment.

Task: I needed to bring data to the discussion instead of just opinions.

Action: I spent a week analyzing the actual problems with the current system. I categorized all comment related bugs from the past year and found that 70% came from just 2 modules, not the overall architecture. I measured development velocity by looking at how long comment features took to ship compared to similar features in other systems. The data showed we were only 15% slower, not the 50% the rebuild advocates claimed. I also estimated rebuild risk by looking at Meta's history of rewrites, finding that 60% took longer than estimated and 30% were eventually abandoned. I presented this analysis to the team with a counter proposal: targeted refactoring of the 2 problematic modules.

Result: Team agreed to the targeted approach based on the data. We refactored the two modules in 8 weeks instead of 6 months. Bug rate dropped 65%. Development velocity improved 20%, close to what the full rebuild promised. My approach of quantifying the actual problem before proposing solutions became a template for future technical decisions.

description: Investigated a recurring problem to find and fix the underlying cause rather than just addressing symptoms.
example_situation: We kept having the same type of outage every few weeks. Investigated systematically and found all incidents traced to connection pool exhaustion under specific conditions.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you did root cause analysis.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Facebook Ads serving had mysterious latency spikes every Tuesday and Thursday afternoon, causing ad delivery to slow down during peak advertiser hours. The on call team had been restarting servers to fix it for 3 months, but nobody knew the root cause.

Task: I decided to investigate and find the actual root cause instead of continuing to treat symptoms.

Action: I correlated the spikes with every possible variable: traffic patterns, deployments, batch jobs, external dependencies. I found the spikes coincided with our ML model refresh jobs, but the model team said their jobs finished hours before the spikes. I dug deeper and discovered the model files were loaded lazily on first request after refresh. Tuesday and Thursday were when we refreshed our two largest models. The first requests after refresh were triggering cold loads that blocked the request threads. The fix was not just prewarming, we needed to load new models in the background while old models continued serving, then swap atomically.

Result: Implemented background model loading with atomic swaps. Tuesday and Thursday latency spikes disappeared completely. Ad serving p99 latency improved 35% because we eliminated all cold load scenarios, not just the bi weekly ones. The pattern was adopted across all ML serving systems at Meta. I presented the investigation methodology at an ads engineering all hands.

description: Made a difficult technical decision that required balancing competing concerns with no perfect answer.
example_situation: Chose eventual consistency over strong consistency for the notification system. Meant occasional duplicate notifications but enabled 10x scale at much lower cost.
typical_question: Tell me about a difficult trade-off you had to make.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram was launching shopping checkout and needed to decide on the consistency model for inventory management. Strong consistency meant no overselling but higher latency and cost. Eventual consistency meant faster checkout but risk of selling items that were already sold.

Task: I needed to make a recommendation knowing there was no perfect answer and both options had real downsides.

Action: I quantified both sides. I analyzed our traffic patterns and found that 99.9% of items had inventory levels where overselling was essentially impossible (more than 100 units). For the 0.1% with low inventory, I calculated the expected oversell rate with eventual consistency: about 50 orders per day out of 500,000. I then analyzed the business impact: oversold orders cost us $15 average in refunds and customer service, totaling $750 per day. Strong consistency would add 200ms latency, which our data showed would reduce checkout completion by 3%, costing roughly $50,000 per day in lost sales. I also proposed a hybrid: eventual consistency for high inventory items, strong consistency only for items with fewer than 10 units.

Result: Team adopted the hybrid approach based on my analysis. We captured 97% of the speed benefit while limiting oversells to approximately 5 per day. Total business impact was $45,000 per day better than pure strong consistency. When we did oversell, we had an automated system to offer customers alternatives with a 10% discount, turning 60% of oversells into successful orders anyway.

description: Came up with a creative or novel solution to a problem that others had struggled with or accepted as unsolvable.
example_situation: Team accepted 30-minute deploy times as normal. I proposed and built a parallel build pipeline that cut deploys to 3 minutes, changing how often we could ship.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you came up with an innovative solution.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram's Explore page had a cold start problem: new users got generic recommendations that performed poorly, leading to 40% higher churn in the first week compared to established users. Previous attempts to solve this with onboarding surveys had failed because users skipped them.

Task: I was challenged to find a way to personalize Explore for new users without requiring any explicit input from them.

Action: I realized we were ignoring valuable signal: the content users engaged with during their first session, before we had any personalization. I proposed a rapid learning system that would update recommendations after every single interaction in real time during the first 24 hours, instead of waiting for daily batch updates. The technical challenge was doing this without overwhelming our ML infrastructure. My innovation was a lightweight embedding model that could run client side on the phone, generating interest signals that we would send to the server to adjust rankings immediately. This avoided the round trip latency of server side inference.

Result: New user engagement on Explore improved 25% in the first week. First week retention improved 8%. The client side embedding approach was novel enough that we filed a patent. The technique was later adopted for Instagram Reels recommendations. This project was highlighted in my promotion packet as demonstrating innovation beyond normal senior engineering work.

description: Received critical or constructive feedback about your work, behavior, or skills. Processed it productively and made meaningful changes.
example_situation: Manager told me my code reviews were too harsh and that junior engineers were intimidated to submit PRs when I was reviewing. Had to change my approach.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you received negative feedback.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: In my performance review, my manager told me that I was seen as unapproachable. She shared feedback from peers that I often dismissed ideas quickly in meetings, and junior engineers felt intimidated asking me questions. This was shocking because I thought I was just being efficient.

Task: I needed to understand the feedback, accept it, and make real changes to how I interacted with my team.

Action: First, I asked for specific examples so I could understand the pattern. I learned that when someone proposed an idea, I would immediately point out flaws without acknowledging the good parts. I started a new practice: before critiquing any idea, I would first state one thing I liked about it. I also scheduled weekly office hours specifically for junior engineers to ask questions in a low pressure setting. I asked a trusted peer to observe me in meetings and give me real time feedback. When I caught myself being dismissive, I would pause, apologize, and ask the person to continue.

Result: Six months later, my manager said the feedback had completely turned around. Junior engineers started seeking me out for advice. I was asked to mentor two new hires specifically because of my improved approachability. In my next review, collaboration was cited as a strength rather than a concern. This experience taught me that being technically right is worthless if people do not want to work with you.

description: Identified and closed a significant gap in your technical or professional skills, often under time pressure.
example_situation: Project required Kubernetes expertise I didn't have. Spent evenings and weekends learning, built a prototype in 2 weeks, became the team's go-to person.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to learn something quickly.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: My team was assigned to build Instagram's new ML recommendation pipeline, but nobody on the team had experience with PyTorch or ML infrastructure. The project had a 3 month deadline and hiring an ML engineer would take longer than that.

Task: I volunteered to learn ML infrastructure quickly enough to lead the technical work.

Action: I created an aggressive learning plan. Week 1: completed PyTorch tutorials and built a simple model. Week 2: studied Meta's internal ML platform documentation and talked to ML engineers on other teams. Week 3: built a prototype pipeline using our actual data. I scheduled daily 30 minute sessions with an ML engineer from the Ads team who agreed to mentor me. I was transparent with my manager about what I did not know and where I needed help. I also documented everything I learned so the knowledge would not be lost.

Result: We launched the ML pipeline on schedule. I went from zero ML experience to being able to debug model training issues and optimize inference latency. I became the go to person for ML questions on my team. I later gave an internal talk called ML for Backend Engineers that helped 50 other engineers ramp up. This experience taught me that I can learn anything with focused effort and the right resources.

description: Took on a role, project, or responsibility significantly outside your normal expertise or comfort level.
example_situation: As a backend engineer, I volunteered to lead the frontend rewrite when no one else would. Had to learn React while also making architectural decisions.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you worked outside your comfort zone.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Our team needed someone to lead a critical data science project analyzing user behavior patterns, but all the data scientists were allocated to other priorities. I was a backend engineer with no formal data science training. The project was blocking a major product decision.

Task: I volunteered to lead the analysis even though it was completely outside my expertise.

Action: I was honest about my skill gap and asked for a data scientist to advise me for 2 hours per week. I learned SQL analytics patterns, basic statistics, and how to use our internal data tools. The hardest part was not the technical skills but presenting findings to non technical stakeholders. I practiced with my manager before every presentation. When I got stuck on statistical methodology, I reached out to the data science team for guidance rather than guessing. I documented my approach so a real data scientist could validate my conclusions.

Result: Delivered the analysis in 4 weeks. The findings showed that 30% of our users had a specific behavior pattern we were not serving well, leading to a new product feature. The data science team validated my methodology and said my analysis was sound. I discovered I enjoyed the detective work of data analysis. I have since taken on 3 more analytics projects and am now considered a hybrid engineer who can do both backend and analytics work.

description: Learned significantly from a mentor, senior colleague, or other source of guidance that accelerated your growth.
example_situation: Staff engineer took me under her wing and taught me how to think about system design at scale. Completely changed how I approach technical problems.
typical_question: Tell me about a mentor who influenced you.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: When I joined Facebook as a mid level engineer, I was technically competent but struggled to have influence beyond my immediate team. I could execute well but did not know how to think strategically about technical direction.

Task: I sought out a mentor who could help me develop the skills to operate at a higher level.

Action: I identified a staff engineer whose work I admired and asked if she would mentor me. She agreed to monthly 1:1s. The most impactful thing she taught me was to always ask why does this matter before diving into how to build it. She would review my design docs and push back on assumptions I had not questioned. She taught me to map stakeholders and understand their incentives before proposing solutions. When I was frustrated about a decision that went against my recommendation, she helped me see that I had failed to build alignment, not that the decision was wrong.

Result: Over 18 months, I transformed from someone who executed tasks to someone who shaped technical direction. I was promoted to senior engineer, with my mentor specifically cited as someone who helped me grow. I now mentor 3 junior engineers using the same frameworks she taught me. The question why does this matter has become my default starting point for any project.

description: Successfully adapted when circumstances changed significantly - new manager, team reorg, pivot in direction, or process changes.
example_situation: In one quarter: team reorg, new manager, new tech stack, and shifted priorities. Had to adapt quickly while still delivering on commitments.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you adapted to change.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: In 6 months, my team went through a reorg that split us across two organizations, we got a new manager with different priorities, and our main project was deprioritized in favor of a completely different initiative. Three people quit due to the uncertainty.

Task: I needed to adapt to constant change while keeping myself and remaining teammates productive and motivated.

Action: I focused on what I could control. I scheduled a 1:1 with my new manager to understand her priorities and how I could help, rather than waiting for direction. When our project was deprioritized, I identified transferable parts of our work that could benefit the new initiative and proposed how to pivot. I became a stabilizing force for the remaining team, organizing weekly coffee chats to maintain morale and share information. I documented tribal knowledge before people left so we would not lose critical context. When I felt frustrated, I vented to friends outside work rather than spreading negativity to the team.

Result: Despite the chaos, our team delivered on the new initiative ahead of schedule. I was recognized for helping maintain team cohesion during a difficult period. Two of the people who initially wanted to quit decided to stay. My new manager cited my adaptability as a key factor in her decision to give me a stretch project the following quarter. I learned that change is constant at fast moving companies, and my response to change is more important than the change itself.

description: Proactively identified and addressed an area for improvement without being asked or required to do so.
example_situation: Noticed senior engineers wrote thorough design docs. Started writing my own before projects, got feedback, and eventually it became a team standard.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you proactively improved yourself.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I noticed that I struggled in meetings with senior leadership. I would get nervous, speak too fast, and fail to land my key points. This was limiting my visibility and impact on important decisions.

Task: I decided to improve my executive communication skills proactively, without being told to.

Action: I watched recordings of colleagues who were effective in leadership meetings and identified patterns: they led with the conclusion, used data sparingly but strategically, and anticipated questions. I joined Toastmasters and practiced speaking weekly. Before important meetings, I would write out my key points and practice delivering them in under 2 minutes. I asked my manager to let me present in lower stakes meetings first so I could build confidence. I also requested feedback after every presentation from someone I trusted.

Result: Within 6 months, my manager commented that my communication had noticeably improved. I was invited to present our team's quarterly results to the VP, something usually reserved for senior engineers. The presentation went well and led to increased visibility for our team. I was later asked to coach other engineers on executive communication. This experience reinforced that soft skills can be learned just like technical skills if you approach them systematically.

description: Stayed current with technology changes, learned new tools or practices, or expanded your expertise over time.
example_situation: Spent 20% time each quarter learning new technologies. This year learned Rust and applied it to performance-critical components, improving throughput 5x.
typical_question: How do you stay current with technology?
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I realized after 3 years at Meta that I had become an expert in our internal systems but was losing touch with industry trends. I worried about becoming too specialized and less valuable if I ever needed to change jobs.

Task: I decided to create a sustainable system for continuous learning that would not interfere with my day job.

Action: I allocated 2 hours every Friday afternoon to learning, treating it as a non negotiable meeting with myself. I created a rotation: one month on a new programming language, one month on a new domain like ML or distributed systems, one month on soft skills like writing or public speaking. I joined internal reading groups and external communities on topics I wanted to learn. I set a goal to apply something I learned to my actual work within 30 days of learning it. I also started writing blog posts internally about what I learned, which forced me to understand topics deeply.

Result: Over 2 years, I learned Rust (applied it to a performance critical component, improving throughput 3x), gained working knowledge of ML (led a recommendation project), and improved my technical writing (now write our team's design docs). My continuous learning habit made me the go to person for evaluating new technologies. When we needed to decide on a new data streaming framework, I was able to make an informed recommendation because I had studied the space. This habit has made me more valuable to my team and more confident in my long term career prospects.

description: Made progress and delivered value despite vague, incomplete, or contradictory requirements from stakeholders.
example_situation: PM said 'make the search faster' with no specific latency target, no budget for infrastructure, and no clarity on which use cases mattered most.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you worked with unclear requirements.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Leadership asked my team to improve the health of the Facebook Groups ecosystem with no specific metrics, no defined scope, and different executives emphasizing different aspects. Some wanted more engagement, others wanted less misinformation, others wanted faster group growth.

Task: I needed to make progress on a vague mandate with contradictory stakeholder input.

Action: I started by defining clarity myself rather than waiting for it. I interviewed 10 stakeholders to understand what they really cared about and found a common thread: they all wanted groups where members actively participated, not just lurked. I proposed healthy engagement as our north star metric and defined it specifically: comments per member per week in groups with more than 50 members. I built a dashboard showing current state and set a target of 20% improvement. When stakeholders pushed their own agendas, I would ask how does that connect to healthy engagement and either incorporate their input or explain why it was out of scope.

Result: Within 3 months, we improved healthy engagement by 25%. Having a clear metric ended the confusion about what we were trying to achieve. Leadership praised the team for bringing clarity to an ambiguous initiative. My approach of defining the problem before solving it became a template for other ambiguous projects. I learned that in the absence of clarity, creating clarity is itself valuable work.

description: Solved a problem or built something with no existing internal solution, playbook, or prior art to reference.
example_situation: First team at the company to build an ML pipeline. No existing infrastructure, no one with experience, no vendor relationships. Had to figure it all out.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you solved a novel problem.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Meta was launching its first hardware product (Portal) and needed to handle device telemetry at scale. Nobody at the company had built IoT infrastructure before. The existing systems were designed for mobile apps, not millions of always on devices sending continuous data.

Task: I was asked to design and build the telemetry system despite having no precedent to follow at Meta.

Action: Since there was no internal precedent, I looked externally. I read papers from AWS and Google about IoT architectures. I reached out to engineers at companies with similar challenges and had informational calls. I identified the key differences from mobile: devices are always connected, data volume is continuous not bursty, and we need to handle unreliable networks gracefully. I built 3 prototype architectures and load tested each. I documented my decision process extensively since I was creating precedent for future hardware products. I also built escape hatches so we could change approaches if my initial design proved wrong.

Result: The telemetry system launched with Portal and handled 10 million devices without issues. The architecture I created became the foundation for all Meta hardware products including Ray Ban Stories and Quest headsets. I wrote a 30 page design document that became required reading for hardware teams. Two years later, my system was still running with minimal changes. I learned that when there is no playbook, creating one carefully is part of the job.

description: Navigated and delivered despite frequently shifting organizational priorities, strategy changes, or pivots.
example_situation: Company priorities changed 3 times in one quarter due to market shifts. Had to re-plan, re-scope, and re-negotiate with stakeholders each time while keeping team motivated.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you dealt with changing priorities.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: In one quarter, my team's priorities changed 4 times. We started on a new Marketplace feature, then pivoted to support a COVID response project, then were asked to help with election integrity, then returned to Marketplace with different requirements. Team morale was suffering from the whiplash.

Task: I needed to deliver value despite constant priority shifts while keeping the team engaged and productive.

Action: I changed how I approached planning. Instead of detailed 3 month roadmaps, I broke work into 2 week increments that could be paused or redirected. I created a document showing all the context switching we had done, which I shared with leadership to advocate for more stability. I was transparent with my team about why priorities were shifting rather than pretending each change was planned. I identified transferable work: code and learnings from one project that could apply to another. I also made sure to celebrate small wins, since we could not celebrate big project completions.

Result: Despite 4 pivots, we shipped meaningful features for 3 of the 4 initiatives. My documentation of context switching costs led leadership to create a more structured process for priority changes the next quarter. Team retention was 100% despite the chaos, because people felt informed and valued. I learned to build flexibility into my planning and to see adaptability as a competitive advantage.

description: Stepped up to own a problem that fell between teams or that no one else was taking responsibility for.
example_situation: Critical customer-facing bug affected 3 teams but each said it wasn't their responsibility. I took ownership, coordinated the investigation, and drove the fix.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you stepped up when ownership was unclear.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: Instagram users were reporting that notifications were arriving hours late, but only for some accounts. The Notifications team said their systems showed delivery within seconds. The iOS team said they were receiving notifications fine. The Account team said account state was normal. Each team had data proving they were not the problem, and users kept complaining.

Task: Nobody owned the problem, so I decided to own it myself and figure out what was actually happening.

Action: I started by reproducing the issue on my own account, which took 2 days of trying different scenarios. I found the pattern: it happened to accounts that had recently switched devices. I traced the flow across all three teams' systems and found the bug: when a user switched devices, there was a race condition where the old device token was sometimes not invalidated immediately, causing notifications to be sent to a device the user no longer had. No single team owned the device switching flow because it touched all of them. I wrote up the root cause, proposed a fix that required changes from both Notifications and Account teams, and offered to coordinate the implementation.

Result: Fixed a bug affecting 2 million users that had been open for 5 months. I became the informal owner of cross team notification issues, which led to me designing a better device switching flow that prevented similar issues. My manager cited this as an example of senior engineer behavior: seeing a problem that needs solving and taking ownership regardless of formal responsibilities.

description: Made a significant decision with limited data, time, or ability to fully analyze the situation.
example_situation: Had to choose between two vendors with only 2 days to evaluate before the contract deadline. Made the best decision possible with available information.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you decided with incomplete information.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: We discovered a critical security vulnerability in our payment system that could be exploited within 72 hours. We had two options: a quick fix that would block the vulnerability but break 5% of legitimate transactions, or a proper fix that would take 2 weeks. We did not have time to fully analyze the business impact of either option.

Task: I needed to make a recommendation to leadership within hours, knowing I did not have complete information.

Action: I gathered what data I could quickly. I estimated the 5% transaction failure would affect about 10,000 users per day and cost roughly $200,000 in lost revenue over 2 weeks. The security team estimated the vulnerability exploitation probability at 30%, with potential impact of $5M plus regulatory consequences. I presented both options with my analysis to leadership, being explicit about what I did not know and what assumptions I was making. I recommended the quick fix and proposed we immediately start the proper fix in parallel. I also outlined a communication plan for affected users.

Result: Leadership approved my recommendation. We deployed the quick fix within 24 hours. The proper fix shipped in 10 days. We lost approximately $180,000 in transactions but avoided the security breach. Post incident analysis showed my estimates were within 20% of actual impact. I learned that in time sensitive situations, a good decision now beats a perfect decision too late, and being explicit about uncertainty builds trust even when you do not have all the answers.

description: Chose a direction when multiple approaches seemed equally valid and there was no clear 'right answer'.
example_situation: Three architectures could work, each with different trade-offs. No clear winner from analysis. Had to make a call, commit, and live with the choice.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you had to choose between multiple options.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: We needed to choose a database for a new Instagram feature. Three options were viable: PostgreSQL (familiar, battle tested), Cassandra (better scale, less familiar), or a new internal database (best performance, least proven). Analysis showed each could work, with different risk and reward profiles. The team was split.

Task: I needed to make a decision and get the team aligned behind it, knowing there was no objectively correct answer.

Action: I created a decision framework. I listed our requirements and assigned weights based on business priorities. I scored each option against the requirements, making my reasoning explicit. The scores were close, but PostgreSQL edged ahead because of team familiarity and our tight timeline. I presented my analysis to the team, acknowledged the valid arguments for other options, and asked if anyone had information that would change the scoring. Nobody did. I made the call for PostgreSQL and committed to revisiting in 6 months. I documented the decision and reasoning so we could learn from it.

Result: PostgreSQL worked well for the feature. At the 6 month review, we confirmed it was handling load fine and decided not to migrate. The decision framework I created was adopted by the team for future technical choices. One engineer who had advocated for Cassandra thanked me for making the process transparent because it let him disagree without feeling dismissed. I learned that when there is no right answer, a clear process for deciding is as important as the decision itself.

description: Aligned stakeholders who had different visions, definitions of success, or expectations for a project.
example_situation: PM, design, and engineering all had different ideas of what 'done' meant for the feature. Had to facilitate alignment before we could make progress.
typical_question: Tell me about a time stakeholders were misaligned.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: We were building a new privacy control for Facebook and the stakeholders could not agree on scope. Legal wanted comprehensive controls covering every data type. Design wanted a simple interface with minimal options. PM wanted to ship fast to meet a regulatory deadline. Engineering wanted to build a reusable framework. Two months of meetings had produced no progress.

Task: I volunteered to facilitate alignment because the project was stuck and I had relationships with all the stakeholders.

Action: I scheduled separate 1:1s with each stakeholder to understand their underlying concerns, not just their stated positions. Legal was worried about regulatory risk. Design was worried about user confusion. PM was worried about their performance review tied to the deadline. Engineering was worried about building something we would have to rebuild. I found common ground: everyone agreed on a core set of controls. I proposed phased delivery: a minimal viable product meeting the deadline with the core controls, followed by comprehensive controls in phase 2. I created a single document showing how each stakeholder's concerns were addressed.

Result: Stakeholders aligned within a week after 2 months of gridlock. We shipped phase 1 on time, meeting the regulatory deadline. Phase 2 shipped 2 months later with the comprehensive controls. Legal praised the phased approach as actually lower risk since we could learn from phase 1. I learned that misalignment usually comes from different unstated concerns, and finding those concerns is more important than debating positions.

description: Navigated and delivered through significant organizational change like restructuring, leadership changes, or acquisitions.
example_situation: Our team was reorged twice in 6 months. Different managers, different priorities each time. Had to keep the project on track through the chaos.
typical_question: Tell me about delivering through organizational change.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: During my team's most important project of the year, we went through a major reorg. Our director left, we were merged with another team, got a new manager who had different priorities, and 3 of our 8 engineers were moved to other teams. The project was 60% complete.

Task: I needed to finish a critical project while the organization was in chaos around us.

Action: I took several steps to maintain continuity. I documented everything about our project: current state, decisions made, and remaining work. This ensured knowledge would not be lost with departing team members. I scheduled a meeting with our new manager within the first week to explain the project's importance and get her buy in. When she suggested deprioritizing it, I prepared a brief showing the business impact and sunk cost, which convinced her to let us finish. I became the informal project lead since our previous lead had left. I also proactively communicated with stakeholders who were confused about whom to contact after the reorg.

Result: We delivered the project on time despite losing 40% of the team. Our new manager cited this as evidence that the merged team could execute. Two engineers who had been uncertain about staying decided to remain because they saw we could deliver despite chaos. I learned that during organizational change, being a source of stability and continuity is extremely valuable.

description: Collaborated effectively with people from different functions (PM, design, data science, QA, etc.) to achieve a shared goal.
example_situation: Partnered closely with data science team to build an ML-powered recommendation feature. Required learning their workflows and finding common language.
typical_question: Tell me about working with a cross-functional team.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I was building Instagram's shopping recommendations feature which required close collaboration with data science for the ML models, design for the UI, PM for requirements, and legal for commerce compliance. Each team had different working styles, timelines, and priorities.

Task: I needed to coordinate all these functions and deliver a cohesive feature.

Action: I started by understanding each team's constraints and communication preferences. Data science needed 3 weeks of lead time for model training. Design wanted to iterate based on user research. Legal needed to review any commerce claims. I created a shared timeline working backwards from launch, with each team's milestones visible to everyone. I learned enough about each domain to have productive conversations: basic ML concepts to discuss model tradeoffs with data science, design principles to give useful feedback on mockups. I scheduled a weekly 30 minute sync with all functions present, keeping it short and focused. Between meetings, I proactively flagged cross functional dependencies before they became blockers.

Result: Launched shopping recommendations on time with strong metrics: 15% click through rate versus our 10% goal. Each function felt their concerns were heard: data science got the training time they needed, design got two iteration cycles, legal approved all commerce copy. The PM specifically thanked me for making the collaboration seamless. I was asked to lead two more cross functional projects based on this experience.

description: Successfully collaborated with teammates or partners across locations, time zones, or working remotely.
example_situation: Built a critical feature with team members in 3 time zones (US, Europe, Asia). Required async communication, detailed documentation, and intentional overlap time.
typical_question: Tell me about collaborating across time zones.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I was leading a WhatsApp feature that required collaboration with engineers in Menlo Park (Pacific time), London (GMT), and Singapore (SGT). We had only 2 hours of overlap between all three time zones. Most of our collaboration had to be asynchronous.

Task: I needed to maintain velocity and quality despite limited synchronous time.

Action: I established asynchronous first practices. I required all decisions and context to be documented in shared docs, not discussed only in meetings. I created a daily handoff process: each location would summarize their progress, blockers, and questions at end of their day for the next location to pick up. I used the 2 hour overlap for high bandwidth discussions only: design reviews, debugging complex issues, and resolving disagreements. I recorded important meetings so people who could not attend could catch up. I was also intentional about relationship building: I scheduled 1:1 video chats with each remote teammate monthly just to connect as humans, not to discuss work.

Result: We shipped the feature on time with zero delays attributable to timezone issues. Team satisfaction scores on collaboration were 4.5 out of 5. The handoff process I created was adopted by two other WhatsApp teams. One Singapore engineer said it was the best remote collaboration experience he had at Meta. I learned that remote collaboration requires more explicit process but can be just as effective as colocated teams.

description: Went out of your way to help a teammate who was struggling, blocked, or overloaded succeed.
example_situation: Colleague was stuck on a bug for days and getting stressed. Spent a full day pair programming with them to unblock and teach the debugging approach.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you supported a teammate.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A teammate was struggling to complete his project on time. He had underestimated the complexity and was working 12 hour days but still falling behind. He was stressed, his code quality was declining, and he was reluctant to ask for help because he felt he should be able to handle it.

Task: I decided to help him even though I had my own deadlines, because I could see he was drowning and it was affecting the whole team's morale.

Action: I approached him privately and offered to pair program on the hardest part of his project. I was careful not to make him feel like I was taking over or judging him. We spent 2 days working together, and I helped him break down the remaining work into smaller pieces. I identified one component that I could take on entirely without needing much context. I also helped him communicate with the PM about realistic timeline expectations, going with him to the meeting so he would not feel alone. I checked in with him daily for the next two weeks to see if he needed anything.

Result: He delivered his project one week late instead of the 4 weeks late it was trending toward. More importantly, he learned techniques for managing complex projects that he used on future work. He told me later that my help came at a point where he was considering quitting because he felt like a failure. Two years later, he was promoted to senior engineer. He still mentions that experience as a turning point. I learned that investing in teammates' success pays dividends far beyond the immediate project.

description: Shared knowledge, context, or expertise to help teammates or the broader organization be more effective.
example_situation: Created comprehensive documentation and ran training sessions for a complex system I built. Reduced my support burden and helped team work independently.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you shared knowledge with your team.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I had built a complex data pipeline that became critical to multiple teams. I was getting 5 to 10 questions per day about how it worked, interrupting my other work. I was the only person who could debug issues or add new features.

Task: I needed to share my knowledge so the team could work independently and I could focus on higher leverage work.

Action: I created multiple layers of documentation. First, an architecture overview for people who needed to understand the system conceptually. Second, operational runbooks for common tasks and troubleshooting. Third, code documentation for people who needed to modify the pipeline. I ran a 2 hour training session and recorded it for future team members. I identified two engineers who were interested in the domain and did deeper knowledge transfer with them, including having them shadow me while I debugged issues. I also created a Slack channel specifically for pipeline questions so knowledge would be shared publicly rather than in private DMs.

Result: Questions to me dropped from 10 per day to 2 per week within a month. Two engineers became capable of handling most issues independently. The documentation became a model for other teams' systems. When I went on vacation, the team handled two incidents without needing to contact me. My manager cited this as an example of scaling impact beyond individual contribution. I freed up approximately 8 hours per week that I redirected to a new high priority project.

description: Provided constructive, actionable feedback to a peer that helped them improve (even if it was uncomfortable).
example_situation: Told a teammate that their design proposal had scalability issues that would cause problems. Awkward at first but they appreciated it and we improved the design together.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you gave difficult feedback to a peer.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A peer was presenting in meetings in a way that was undermining his effectiveness. He would interrupt others, dismiss alternative viewpoints quickly, and get defensive when challenged. Others were starting to avoid meetings with him. I had a good relationship with him and could see he was unaware of the impact.

Task: I decided to give him feedback that could help his career, even though it was uncomfortable and risky.

Action: I asked if I could give him some feedback and scheduled time when we would not be rushed. I started by affirming that I valued him and wanted to see him succeed. I was specific about behaviors I had observed: in Tuesday's meeting, you interrupted Sarah twice when she was sharing her analysis. I explained the impact: I noticed Sarah stopped contributing after that, and we lost her perspective. I avoided generalizations like you always interrupt people. I asked if this matched his self perception and listened to his response. He was initially defensive, so I gave him space to process. I followed up a week later to see how he was feeling about the conversation.

Result: He thanked me for the feedback, saying no one had ever told him this directly. Over the following months, I noticed him actively working on listening more in meetings. His reputation improved and he was included in more strategic discussions. When he was promoted the next year, he specifically thanked me for the feedback as a factor in his growth. I learned that giving difficult feedback is an act of care, not confrontation, when done with good intent and specific examples.

description: Actively sought, listened to, and incorporated feedback from others to improve your work or approach.
example_situation: Asked colleague to review my architecture proposal. They pointed out a major flaw in my approach. Redesigned based on their feedback and ended up with a better solution.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you acted on feedback from others.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I had written what I thought was a strong design document for a new caching layer. I sent it to a senior engineer for review, expecting minor comments. Instead, she came back with fundamental concerns about my approach, saying it would not scale and the cost model was wrong.

Task: I needed to evaluate her feedback objectively rather than defensively and incorporate it if it was valid.

Action: My first instinct was to defend my design, but I forced myself to pause and really understand her concerns. I scheduled a 1:1 to walk through her feedback in detail. She was right: I had made assumptions about traffic patterns that were not supported by data. Instead of getting defensive, I asked her to help me understand the correct approach. I rewrote significant portions of the design based on her input. I also added a section acknowledging the tradeoffs and risks she had identified. Before resubmitting, I asked her to review again to make sure I had addressed her concerns properly.

Result: The revised design was approved and implemented successfully. It handled 3x the load I originally planned for because of the scaling improvements she suggested. My manager later told me the senior engineer had specifically mentioned that she was impressed by how I received feedback. I have since adopted a practice of explicitly asking what am I missing or what would you do differently to invite critical feedback. This experience taught me that the goal is to build the best system, not to be right.

description: Prioritized helping teammates get unblocked over your own work when they needed it.
example_situation: Teammate was blocked on their launch-critical work by an issue in my domain. Dropped my own project to spend 2 days helping them debug and fix it.
typical_question: Tell me about a time you unblocked a teammate.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: A teammate was blocked on her launch critical project by an issue in the authentication system, which I had built. She had spent 2 days trying to debug it herself. Her launch was in 5 days and my own project also had a deadline, but her launch had higher business impact.

Task: I decided to prioritize unblocking her over my own work because her project was more important to the company.

Action: I dropped my current work and scheduled a pairing session with her immediately. Within 2 hours, I identified the issue: a race condition in session token refresh that only manifested under her specific usage pattern. The fix was straightforward once we understood the problem. I implemented the fix that afternoon and stayed late to ensure it deployed successfully. I also updated the documentation to warn about this edge case and added a test to prevent regression. I then worked extra hours over the weekend to catch up on my own project.

Result: Her project launched on time and exceeded its success metrics. My project was 2 days late, but my manager supported the tradeoff because the business impact was clear. She later returned the favor by helping me with a problem in her domain. We developed a reciprocal relationship where we would prioritize each other's blockers. My manager cited this as an example of team first behavior in my performance review.

description: Effectively communicated with and managed expectations of your manager or leadership.
example_situation: Proactively updated my manager on risks and timeline changes rather than waiting for her to ask. She appreciated the transparency and could help remove blockers.
typical_question: Tell me about how you work with your manager.
strong_hire_example:
Situation: I joined a new team with a manager who had 10 direct reports and limited time. Previous engineers on the team complained about lack of support and guidance. I needed to make our limited 1:1 time effective.

Task: I decided to proactively manage the relationship rather than waiting for my manager to direct me.

Action: I created a shared document for our 1:1s where I would add agenda items throughout the week. I categorized items as FYI (no action needed), input requested (need her perspective), or decision needed (need her approval). This let her prepare and made our 30 minutes efficient. I sent a weekly email summary every Friday: what I accomplished, what I am working on next week, any risks or blockers. I learned her priorities and communication preferences: she cared most about launch dates and cross team dependencies. When I had bad news, I delivered it early with a proposed solution rather than waiting until it became a crisis. I also asked her directly how I could make her job easier.

Result: My manager told me I was the easiest person on her team to manage because she always knew where things stood. I got more of her attention for strategic discussions because we did not waste time on status updates. When I needed her help removing a blocker with another team, she responded within hours because she trusted my judgment. I was promoted within a year, and she cited our effective working relationship as evidence that I could operate independently. I learned that managing up is not about impressing your boss but about making their job easier while getting what you need to succeed.
